Investigator returns the vacuum cleaner to the closet and produces a mini-vac from Detective Hugo's crime bag.
(to Eugene, referring to ther mini-vac)
May I?
Clean the whole house if you want.
(taking Eugene's lead)

Actually, the kitchen needs doing. The Investigator switches on the mini-vac to take a speci from the floor, then promptly kills the machine.  Looking the Investigator notices the trail of Eugene's perspirati on the highly polished floor leading to the spiral stairc Eugene, reading the Investigator's mind, goes to call out the words remain frozen on his tongue.  Hugo follows his superior as they start to descend the stairs.  Irene and are left staring at one another. INT.  CONDO - STAIRCASE.  DAY. JEROME catches the merest glimpse of the INVESTIGATOR and DETECTIVE HUGO before he slips behind a doorway in Eugene condominium. Jerome anxiously regards Eugene's empty wheelchair sittin there.  On the stairs, Hugo's phone rings.
(into phone, increasingly encouraged)
Yes?...Yes... yes ... The Investigator is already at the foot of the stairs in Eugene's condo when the Detective calls to him.
(urgent, to Investigator)

Come quickly.  We  have him. The Investigator's eyes light up.  He retraces his steps up the staircase after Detective Hugo. INT.  JEROME'S CONDOMINIUM.  DAY. JEROME, white as a ghost, climbs the stairs, emerging int own condominium.  He embraces the beaming EUGENE, still s on the sofa.
(numb)
How are you, Jerome?
Not bad, Jerome.
How the hell did you get here.
(deadpan)

I could always walk.  I've been faking it. Jerome almost laughs, despite the situation.  Only now do notice Irene on the other side of the room, her mind raci She looks at Jerome and Eugene together and runs from the apartment.
(calling after her)

Irene. Jerome goes to follow but Eugene stops him. INT.  CRIME LABORATORY.  DAY. An EXTREME CLOSE UP of dried blood - brittle and cracking a pair of soiled latex gloves.  A latex head mask, suit o clothes and shoe covers are similarly caked.  The INVESTI and DETECTIVE HUGO watch as a white-coated FORENSIC TECHN feeds a minute sample of the dried blood into an analyzer The INVESTIGATOR wanders over to a one-way glass window t which he can observe DIRECTOR JOSEF, sitting numb but str serene in an interrogation room.  The Investigator, in a of shock himself, cannot yet bring himself to believe wha plainly obvious.
(gazing at the Director, struggling to come to grips with the turn of events)
This can't be him. The Detective regards his superior incredulously, intrigu he could still cling so stubbornly to his theory in the f such overwhelming evidence.
(intrigued)
We found his spit in the dead director's eye. He's signed a confession--supplied us with the suit he wore on the night.  What more do you want?
(a trace of desperation, grasping at straws)

Luca could still be an accomplice. The Investigator turns away, unwilling or unable to accep explanation.  Hugo regards the Investigator with a trace sympathy.  He furtively retrieves the Investigator's tiss from the trash. INT.  GATTACA.  DAY. JEROME sits in a formal briefing room with the other CREW MEMBERS of his mission, receiving their final pre-flight instructions.  LAMAR looks on approvingly.
--Finally, I'd like to welcome Navigator Morrow on his debut mission--if we get lost out there, nobody has a map of the heavens in his head like Jerome. Jerome looks up bashfully.
(adopting a more serious tone)

I'm gratified that there is no longer a cloud hanging over tomorrow's launch.  Now we can put this unpleasantness behind us and concentrate on the task at hand.  I don't have to tell you how important this mission is--the Belt could hold the key to the origin of life - why we are what we are. (injecting a note of levity)
I know many of you have been asking that question about  me for long enough. (referring to a projected photograph of a misshapen asteroid behind his head)
Gaspra--how could something so ugly hold so many beautiful secrets? Polite smiles from his colleagues.

Enjoy your final evening with your families. We'll all be a year older when they see us next.  And don't be late tomorrow.  You don't want to miss this. We focus on Jerome.  He appears to have his head in the h already. INT.  CRIME LAB.  NIGHT. The tormented INVESTIGATOR lies on the floor of his lab, at the ceiling.  he winces in discomfort.  He is lying on something.  He rolls over and retrieves the irritation fr pocket.  It is the "ESC" computer key he prized from Jero keyboard. He gazes at the key for a moment and then gets to his fee resurrects an old fingerprint kit from a cupboard.  Caref removing the key from the specimen bag - marked, "MORROW, Jerome" - he begins to dust it for a fingerprint. He places the key under a camera.  The enlarged print app on the lefthand side of his computer screen.  The word "M blinks onto the screen.  However the face that appears fr computer's databank is not that of "MORROW, Jerome" but "LUCA, Vincent".  The Investigator regards the photograph disbelief. DETECTIVE HUGO casually enters the lab, something odd in nonchalant demeanor.
(excited)
Hugo!  I've found him!
I've found him too.
(not listening, referring to his discovery)
A fingerprint.  There's something to be said for nostalgia. (realizing what Hugo has said)
What did you find? Hugo puts a specimen bag on the counter.  It contains the Investigator's discarded tissue.  The Investigator does not recognize it.
It's not  exactly him.
(interest piqued)
Where did you get this? The Investigator immediately deposits the tissue into an analyzer.
(referring to the tissue)

But this man does share some common characteristics with your suspect.  Not so many but  enough .  It appears the eyelash has a brother--of a kind. The Investigator realizes the significance and looks guil to Hugo.  Hugo exits the lab, leaving the Investigator to at his own FACE in his analyzing machine. INT.  GATTACA - JANITOR'S LOCKER ROOM.  NIGHT. CAESAR, the old janitor, enters the locker room.  He is a wearily open his locker when he senses another presence i room. He turns to find JEROME sitting there on a bench.  Althou clearly delighted, CAESAR tries to disguise his pleasure.
So you've finally seen sense and come back to your old job, Vincent.
Not yet, I'm afraid.
No?  What's keeping you?
I guess I'm a slow learner.
I guess so. (looking up through the small window)
Well, while you're up there, maybe you could tidy the place up a bit.
I'll see what I can do. The two men embrace, Caesar breaking off before Jerome.
And don't go getting everybody lost out there. You'll give us a bad name.  You won't have me to keep an eye on you, you know.
(glancing to Caesar's locker)
By the way, I left some trash in your locker.
(happy to oblige)

I'll take care of it. Jerome departs.  Caesar watches him go and turns back to locker.  He opens it to find a brand new, high-tech teles sitting inside. The old janitor gets over his surprise and beams broadly he looks back in Jerome's direction but he has gone.  The old janitor cannot help himself and reverently reaches fo telescope's eyepiece. INT.  GATTACA - COMPUTER COMPLEX.  NIGHT. In the dimly-lit, empty computer complex, JEROME takes a look around.  He sits at his computer, one final time rep the graphic representation of his path through the cosmos he is on the eve of taking for real. He notices the key missing from his keyboard.  Instantly realizing the significance, he rises from his seat to fle

Vincent-- Jerome is stopped in his tracks by the sound of his given and the voice that calls it. He makes no further attempt to flee but turns to face his pursuer.  The Investigator steps out of the shadows.
Vincent, what are you running from?
(disturbingly calm)
From Vincent. The two men face each other for the first time in a long time.  The Investigator is transfixed by Jerome's face - scarcely able to believe his eyes.
Has it been so long, you don't remember who I am?
(nodding to the Investigator's badge)
Maybe it's  you who's forgotten. (meeting his gaze)
What are you doing here, Anton? It is finally apparent the Investigator is Jerome's young brother Anton [AS WE SHALL REFER TO THE INVESTIGATOR FOR REST OF THE FILM].
I could ask  you the same question. (glancing to the impressive complex)
I have a  right to be here,  you don't. Jerome smiles at him condescendingly.
You almost sound like you believe that.
(ignoring the remark, extending his hand)
Come with me now, Vincent.  You've gone as far as you can go.
(refusing Anton's hand, glancing to the telescope above them)
There are a few million miles to go yet.
(adamant)
It's over.
(shaking his head)
Is that the only way you can succeed, Anton, to see me fail?
It's for the best.
(increasingly angered)
God, even  you want to tell me what I  can't do. In case you hadn't noticed, Anton, I don't need rescuing.  But  you did, once. Anton is clearly stung by the memory.
(goading)
Well?  You have all the answers.  How is that possible?
(resolute)
You didn't beat me that day.  I beat  myself .
Who are you trying to convince?
(angry)
I will prove it to you.  Come swim with me now, Vincent.  Now--tonight. Jerome regards Anton with a knowing smile.  Somewhere in a phone rings.

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. IRENE'S CAR OUTSIDE CONDOMINIUM COMPLEX. NIGHT

text: IRENE, sitting in her car outside Jerome's condominium, h her portable phone.  In her agitation, her finger involun goes to her pulse.  She catches herself and removes the f from her wrist as if it has burned her.  She exits the ca INT.  JEROME'S CONDOMINIUM/EUGENE'S CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. IRENE quietly knocks on Jerome's door but there is no res Trying the handle, the door opens.  Her curiosity takes h inside.  All is quiet.  IRENE calls out.

Hello. No reply.  Irene hesitantly ventures further, drawn to th spiral staircase.  She tentatively makes her way down the and into Eugene's dimly lit condominium.  With wonder and reverence, she examines the instruments and samples laid Eugene's work benches.  She opens the refrigerator in the bathroom and inspects the samples and sachets.  Finally s regards the empty incinerator.
Quite something, isn't it? Irene turns. Eugene has entered through the mirrored door, not at all displeased by her unexpected visit.
(referring to the incinerator)
That's where we get rid of the traces of him although we never truly succeeded.
I've been looking for him.  Do you know where he is?
(unconcerned)
He's probably leaving some more of me around the place before he goes. Eugene idly inspects one of the blood sachets.
Don't be deceived, Irene.  These are just the clothes.  He has to wear them. Something I could never do.
What's wrong with him?
(sympathetic smile)
You have more in common than you know. Irene's hand involuntarily goes to her heart.
But they say  his is already ten thousand beats overdue.  I have my doubts. (wry smile)

For all my gifts, they could never engineer me a heart like Vincent's. Irene turns back to the incinerator, lost in though. EXT.  BEACH.  NIGHT. JEROME and ANTON walk down a dune together towards the be far from Gattaca - an ocean beach pounded by an angry, bl sea.  Jerome picks up a sharp piece of shell and slices t of his thumb.  A drop of blood oozes out.  He offers the to Anton but Anton does not take it. Both men begin to disrobe.  The brothers stand beside eac on the sand once again - Anton still the more athleticall of the two. Together, they enter the raging surf.  Diving through the breaking waves, they begin to swim. In the moonlit night, we watch their two bodies swimming side.  They swim a long distance, Anton waiting for his b to tire.  But the pace does not slacken.  Anton pulls up water.  Sensing his brother is no longer beside him, Jero pulls up.  They tread water several yards apart.
(attempting to conceal his distress)
How are you doing this, Vincent?  How have you done  any of this?

Now is your chance to find out. Jerome swims away a second time.  Anton is forced to foll once again.  Angry now, gritting his teeth, Anton calls upon the same determination we have witnessed during his constant swimming in the pool.  He puts on a spurt, slowl reeling in Jerome. Anton gradually draws alongside Jerome, certain that this will demoralize his older brother.  But Jerome has been f waiting for him to catch up.  Jerome smiles at Anton.  Wi almost a trace of sympathy, he forges ahead again.  Anton forced to go with him.  They swim again for a long distan It is Anton who gradually becomes demoralized - his strok weaken, his will draining away.  Anton pulls up, exhauste fearful.  Jerome also pulls up.  However his face display of Anton's anxiety. They tread water several yards apart.  The ocean is chopp now.  The view of the lights on the shore is obscured by peaks of the waves.
(panic starting to show)
Vincent, where's the shore?  We're too far out. We have to go back!
(calling back)
Too late for that.  We're closer to the other side. Anton looks towards the empty horizon.
What other side?  How far do you want to  go?! Do you want to drown us both? (becoming hysterical)
How are we going to get  back?! Jerome merely smiles back at his younger brother, a distu serene smile.
(eerily calm)

You wanted to know how I did it.  That's how I did it, Anton.  I never saved anything for the swim back. Anton stares at Jerome, aghast.  The two men face each ot silence, treading water several yards apart in the dark, ocean. Jerome turns and heads back towards the shore.  Anton is alone with the terrifying realization.  The only sound, t and the water. EXT.  CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. JEROME, dishevelled and distressed, arrives back at the condominium.  He notices IRENE standing at the edge of th She turns.  He approaches her.  They stand several yards Looking into each other's eyes, they do not speak.  Jerom abruptly pulls a hair from his head - for once one of his
(wry smile, offering the hair to Irene)
Here, take it. Irene takes the hair, the significance not lost on her.
(echoing Irene's words from their first encounter)
If you're still interested, let me know. Irene contemplates the hair in her fingers for a moment, deliberately lets it fall to the ground.
(never taking her eyes from him, echoing Jerome's words from their first encounter)

Sorry, the wind caught it. Once again there is not a breath of wind.  The hair lies, plainly visible on the edge of the pool. From an upstairs window, EUGENE observes the couple. INT.  JEROME'S CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. We watch the silhouette of IRENE and JEROME making love i the bedroom. INT.  EUGENE'S CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. EUGENE, sitting in his darkened room, unscrews the cap of plastic container and places it on a nearby table.  We re on Eugene's face as he opens his fly. INT.  JEROME'S CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. IRENE and JEROME lie in bed together after making love. once Jerome is able to sleep unconcerned.  It is Irene wh awake, head against JEROME'S chest, listening to the soun his erratically beating heart.  However it has a soothing effect on her. She kisses Jerome and reluctantly rises from the bed.
(awakening)
A year is a long time.

Not so long--just once around the sun. Jerome smiles.  For once Irene seems to be looking forwar to the trip.  She exits the room. INT.  INCINERATOR.  MORNING. Inside the incinerator, JEROME scrapes away at himself - final time.  He wistfully regards the brush in his hand. INT.  EUGENE'S CONDOMINIUM.  MORNING. JEROME, dressed for his departure, emerges down the spira staircase into Eugene's condo.  Jerome notices several su at the foot of the stairs. EUGENE wheels into the room.
I have your samples ready.
(confused)
Have you forgotten?  I don't need any samples where I'm going.
(meeting Jerome's gaze)

No, but you might need them when you get back. Eugene wheels across the room and opens the mirrored door water vapor billows out.  Jerome regards Eugene. Eugene leads Jerome inside for the first time. Inside are two rows of four identical, industrial refrige They contain thousands of blood and urine specimens. Jerome regards them with awe and more than a little uneas
Everything you need to last you two lifetimes. EUGENE points out an extra specimen of semen in the first refrigerator.
There's an extra specimen.  I wish I could give it to her myself. (afterthought)
But then, you always were better at being me. Eugene leads the way out of the refrigerator room.
(struggling to come to terms with the discovery)
Why have you done this?
(as he seals the mirrored door)
In case you get back before I do.
Where are you going?
(glancing to the suitcases)
I'm travelling too. Jerome goes to question Eugene's travel plans but thinks of it.  He kneels before his friend and embraces him.
Thank you.
I got the better end of the deal.  I just lent you my body--you lent me your dream. Jerome smiles and hugs Eugene a final time.  Eugene stuff envelope into Jerome's pocket.
(referring to the note, glancing heavenwards)

Not until you're upstairs. Jerome exits.  Eugene watches him go. INT.  GATTACA - DEPARTURE LOUNGE.  NIGHT. JEROME enters a large holding area along with his other e CREW MEMBERS. Jerome's heart sinks as he recognizes LAMAR, greeting the for one final unexpected substance test.  His colleagues groan good-naturedly but it is clearly far more than an inconvenience to Jerome.  He looks towards the door he ha entered but there is no way back.  One by one the crew ar ushered behind a screen.  Before he can think of a way ou is Jerome's turn.  He enters the cubicle.
(as he takes the plastic cup from Lamar)
What's this, Lamar?
New policy. From behind, we see Jerome unzip his fly.  However for on Jerome does not urinate on cue - unused to operating his equipment in front of the physician.
(intrigued by the out-of-character discharge)
Flight got you nervous?
There's a problem, Lamar.
(apparently not listening)
Did I ever tell you about my son, Jerome?  He's a big fan of yours.  He wants to apply here. Jerome realizes he has no choice.  Resigned to his fate, begins to fill the cup.
(as he urinates)
Just remember, Lamar, I could have gone up and back and nobody would have been the wiser--
(cutting him off)

--Unfortunately my son's not all that they promised.  But then, who know what he could do. Lamar takes the cup from Jerome in his gloved hand.  Jero anxiously watches his sample poured into the analyzer. Confirming Jerome's worst fears, the face of 20-YEAR-OLD appears on the computer screen.  However Lamar does not l the screen.  He stares Jerome in the eye.
For future reference-- (a brief glance to where Jerome has just zipped his fly)
--righthanded men don't hold it with their left.  It's just one of those things. Never lookig at the screen, Lamar presses a button marked "VALID".
(knowing smile)

Have a safe trip, Vincent. Jerome exits up a long enclosed escalator, realizing that has known all along. INT.  EUGENE'S CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. EUGENE knocks back a vodka.  With a certain reverence he his silver medal around his neck. INT.  ESCALATOR.  NIGHT. At the top of a long escalator, the door to a craft is se INT.  EUGENE'S CONDOMINIUM.  NIGHT. Eugene's wheelchair, empty, sits beside the door of the incinerator, also secured. EXT.  LAUNCHPAD.  NIGHT. A CLOSE UP of the flame of a rocket's engines igniting - ball of fire engulfs the launchpad - filling the screen. INT.  EUGENE'S CONDOMINIUM - INCINERATOR.  NIGHT. Inside the incinerator another ball of fire - this time engulfing the unseen figure of EUGENE.  We glimpse the me around his neck, melting in the fierce blaze. EXT.  GATTACA - LAUNCHPAD.  NIGHT. As we have seen so often in the past, a rocket launches i the sky over Gattaca - however on this occasion it carrie Jerome. INT.  SPACECRAFT.  NIGHT. We focus on JEROME's face - seeing little if any of the c Jerome's eyes are closed.  His head is still - alarmingly Could the launch itself have been too much for him?  He h thoguhts in his head.

We came from the stars so they say, now it's time to go back.  If I was conceived today, I would not get beyond eight cells, and yet here I am.  In a way they were right, I don't have the heart for this world. (pause)

The question is, why am I having so much trouble dying? Jerome's eyes blink open.  He holds the letter from Eugen his hand.  It contains no words, merely a lock of EUGENE' - for once preserved solely for its sentimental value.  T hair, weightless, floats off the page. We focus on a porthole looking out upon a starscape.

As we pan across the constellations, a title is superimpo upon the starscape: In a few short years, scientists will have completed the Human Genome Project, the mapping of all the genes that make up a human being. After 4 billion years of evolution by the slow and clumsy method of natural selection, we have now evolved to the point where we can direct our own evolution. The first title is replaced in the heavens by a second ti If only we had aquired this knowledge sooner, the following people would never have been born: A succession of portraits and photographs of RENOWNED and HISTORIC FIGURES fades in and out of the constellations - accompanying titles list their affliction rather than the accomplishments.
Blind from birth NAPOLEON BONAPARTE
Epileptic
Arthritic
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (Lou Gerhig's Disease)
Alzheimer's Disease
Blind and deaf
Lou Gerhig's Disease JACKIE JOYNER-KERSEE
Asthmatic

Chronic invalid The face of Charles Darwin fades off and another title ap out of the stars. Even Charles Darwin, the man who told of the survival of the fittest, numbered amongst our frailest. The title fades off and is replaced by one final title in night sky. Of course, the other birth that would surely never have taken place is your own.
